PDF page swiping or scrolling is a much needed feature. When you import a PDF for annotation, you've to click on the arrow every time to navigate between the pages. Imagine editing a 100 page PDF and you aren't able to swipe across pages. Bad experience for a premium price.

UPDATE: Gotta say that while this app was the best at the time of downloading, the lack of searching through notes (either handwriting or searching) and difficulty combing through my pages of notes (and massive note sizes) has pushed me to other apps. Good: -It works well, and the interface is nice. -It is also very nice to be able set it up to erase with your finger (after taking notes with your stylus wacom or active based). It is relatively easy to export to jpg or locally to the device or google drive. -There is a cast button that lets you cast to google devices... like nest hubs and chrome cast... I have not tried in the office with Google Meet conference hardware, but will update when I do. -They don't have their own weird cloud. This app is standalone and does not need an account with whoever devs Squid. -You can lasso inserted photos and move them Bad: -The erase with your finger option is negated by the fact that when the palm rejection doesn't work (which happens often), ends up erasing your notes (I guess this is more problematic for me since I am left handed). I had to turn it off. -There is no option to auto backup to Google Drive or OneDrive. This is particularly upsetting, because unless you remember to manually backup, you may lose your device and your notes. To do that you would have to use Dropbox or Box (i am not about to get another service just for this app). Also, given that those two are the most popular cloud services for business, it makes it impossible for me to propose the adoption of this app at work. -This app is subscription based. Premium features cost per month/year... not single purchase like INKredible. I guess you can buy features one at a time, but that doesn't seem like a good idea to me. I am still on the fence of which app to keep.

I'm disappointed. Lines are jagged - there is a feature request for 7 years to fix this. Few tools there and yet you need multiple clicks for tool changing - try draw simple circle/rectangle/line diagram (requested by 600+ users more then one year ago). Blending method of highlighter tool is lowering contrast and readability of highlighted text. In addition text written on a highlighted line is rendered differently. If you move previously written text on a highlighted line, text is still rendered as it would below highlight. There are some interesting features like different paper styles (lines, squares, dots etc), I like workflow based on a vector engine - size changing, colors etc. However I don't understand how application with subscriber model and long history still have so immature feature bugs for such a long time. I'll bee looking for an alternative.

I am trying this because I got a 2-in-1 chromebook, but it really makes me miss Lecture Notes, which has been my favorite note taking app for years. Good: There is no lag when writing. There are several background patterns to choose from. Cons: The writing often shows as shaky, even though I have a pretty steady hand. I can't seem to get it to ignore my hand resting on the screen when I'm writing with a stylus. I don't understand the scroll. I have now twice lost my notes while writing, because it is set to "infinite" page size, and some gesture from my hand caused me to scroll apparently miles away from my writing. If I "print" the page, I can see that the writing is still there somewhere, but I cannot find it by zooming and scrolling around. There doesn't seem to be a way to ask for help, only a page for offering suggestions or making feature requests. That's why I'm writing here.

I use the app to replace blackboard while giving math lectures at a university (over Zoom). I typically create partially filled pdf slides and then write on them while lecturing, using a 10.5 inch android tablet with pen. Three things would vastly improve the app for me: 1) while the pen is hovering over the screen, there is a tiny circle. However, it's so small that the student's can barely see it. I don't know if this is something that can be done inside the app, but I would love if I could change the way this circle looks and use it as a pointer. 2) The blue bar on top takes up about 20% of the screen while not containing anything too useful. The app looks like it thinks that my screen is much smaller than it actually is. The bar doesn't go away when my tablet is connected over Zoom and I am sharing its screen. 3) I change colors often. I like the preselected colors and appreciate that it takes only 3 taps to change color (unlike other apps), but I would appreciate if the (much thinner version of) the blue bar on top had a few color disks to choose from (of colors customizable by the user) and color change would take one tap, not 3. 4) The last complaint is just a minor one, but maybe easily fixable: when I write on my slides (created with beamer, LaTeX, of standard size) and I want to add a page, I struggle to find the correct size to match the other pages. As a result, the resulting class notes have pages that are suddenly twice as big, or the pen becomes too thin, etc... Otherwise, great job, this is a very nice app!

I have been using NoteShelf since Aug 2020. I use note writing apps a lot for studying AI and stats (a lot of equations, diagrams and images) so it is an absolute critical piece of software, besides having decent hardware (Tab S7). After all these months, I finally decided to make the jump over to Squid. Bought the in-app tool pack, backup and PDF import.The overall experience have been great thus far. #################################### PLUS:: [ Palm rejection is MUCH MUCH better on Squid than on NoteShelf. I think it might be due to Squid requiring 2 fingers for pan. This was a MAJOR PITA for me using NoteShelf. ] - [ My backup EMR pen from my Likebook Muses worked way better than on NoteShelf. Even the eraser works on Squid, which doesn't work on NoteShelf. ] - [ I screenshot a lot (off lecture videos) for my notes. On Noteshelf, my palm kept accidentally selecting my screenshot-images because the app registered it as a long press. On Squid, selection of images requires the use of the lasso tool, so no such problem. ] - [ Pressure sensitivity works well. Makes my handwriting look a lot better. ] - [ Squid's shape tool is a lot more use-able compared to Noteshelf. I can be very precise. ] - [ I exported my NoteShelf notes as PDFs. Squid opened them up like a charm. ] - [ If we put font choice aside, typing text with a bluetooth keyboard is a lot less buggy on Squid vis-a-vis NoteShelf. ] - [ 1000% zoom. I can pack a lot into an A4 sheet. Especially useful when writing cheat-sheets. ] - [ There is backup to a local folder. This plays well for me as I have FolderSync Pro. No such feature on NoteShelf. ] - [ I can set what action to take when I press my S-pen button. No such setting on NoteShelf. ] ####################### CONS:: [ Eraser size needs improving. The smallest setting (1mm) is still too big when you zoom in to 600%-1000%. Only way to work around is to not write at such high zoom levels. ] - [ Eraser shape is square. NoteShelf is circle, a shape that is a lot easier to get into the little nooks and crannies, especially on a page pack full of notes ] - [ One extra tap to switch out to other tools (i.e. lasso, highlight or shape tool.) ] - [ Lasso selection can be a bit tricky if handwriting and image are too close. Noteshelf doesn't have this issue: I usually just draw a small lasso circle in the middle of the image to avoid all the handwrite all around. ] - [ Not sure if the automated backup is actually working *Testing in progress ] - [ Cloud backup ONLY has Dropbox and Box. No Google Drive. NoteShelf has Drive, Evernote and Dropbox. ] - [ Whenever you zoom, the zoom % box (that lets you know what percentage zoom you're at and to lock it if you wish) is right smack in the center-top. Very irritating when you're trying to write from top-down. With NoteShelf, I was at least able to drag it into the corner. This box should really default to a corner. ] - [ No audio record. Noteshelf has it. ] - [ Access to other page templates requires a monthly subscription on Squid. Noteshelf's page templates are free. With PDF import, this is easy to go around on Squid: I just export as PDF from NoteShelf's template and use it as and when when on Squid. ] - [ No bookmarking. Noteshelf has it. ]

As someone coming from an iPad to a Tab S7+, Squid is a great alternative to notability, arguably the best note taking app on iPad. Squid is very responsive and the writing comes out clean. I like the organization options and having it as a PDF editor is great too. I have to take massive points off for one single thing that is such a downer that it frustrates me on an otherwise great app. This app, a note taking app, is not in fullscreen mode. That's right. The navigation bar is there at all times. It's incredibly frustrating to accidentally hit any of the buttons on the navigation bar which I have already done plenty of times in my first day using this app. An option for fullscreen mode would make this app so much better. As is, the navigation bar being there is massive points off and, maybe over time, a deal breaker. For now, I've resorted to using a fullscreen immersive app that forces the device to have it in fullscreen mode at all times when activated. A workaround, but not a solution.

I've been using Squid every day for two different classes, so about 6 months total, and it's really a great app. I can only really think of some minor suggestions for improvement, such as sync across devices, and the ability to add to remove elements after selecting them with the selection tool. And it would be nice to have the ability to lock some items in place, so they don't get moved or selected accidentally later. I often make tables and being the force them into the background after drawing them, similar to how an imported PDF functions, would be nice. That's about all I can think of for now. But this app is so much better than all the others I've looked it, it's hard to complain too much. I especially like how it works so well with my S Pen to suppress any contact my hand makes from disturbing my canvas.

This is generally a very good app. I mostly use it for marking up PDFs, which it is quick at and saves them within the app as a separate file, rather than overwriting the original PDF. You can later export the marked up PDF which is great. The two most annoying things I find is, firstly, there is no option to swipe to the next page. Most of the time I don't need to do it, but it would be a nice option that is available in other apps. The more annoying thing, that I haven't found in another app and so would really make this app stand out is the ability to navigate a PDF using the built in bookmarks. I am often trying to navigate a multi-thousand page PDF and find myself lost only having the option to look at all the pages in a thumbnail view or to scroll the page number (not even type one in). If a bookmark navigation feature was added I really think that would transform my usage of this app.

This is definitely the best note taking app on Android. There are tons of options for paper type (lined, grid, engineering, sports layouts, etc.) and great options for writing with colors, shapes and lines. Adding pictures and screenshots is very easy. Using it on a Samsung Galaxy Tab with S-Pen is a breeze. I used it for 1.5 semesters of college and absolutely loved it. That's where my biggest issue with the app comes in. There is no syncing of your notes to any account (there is backup and restore, but the functionality is not the same). I had my tablet stolen halfway through this past spring semester and lost all of my notes from the past 1.5 semesters. While I could have backed up the notes, there should seriously be a sync functionality so you can edit notes on multiple devices and even view on a computer. Overall very good app. Just backup your notes (And please add this sync functionality, Steadfast!).

Unintelligent backup-exporting of PDFs also an issue - unchanged files should be ignored. Badly needs a dark mode. Bottom-line, the app is fairly stagnant - no significant upgrades in a very long time. I'm reconsidering my subscription.

Edit: Developers have sat on the app without providing new features. Subscriptions are a two way street, users pay developers a reoccuring fee in return for improvements. Sure there is the occasional "bug fix and optimization" update, but where is the Google Drive sync? Where is the handwriting search? Compared to other apps like LectureNotes and OneNote, Squid is very minimal and honestly it just doesn't compare.   Compared to LectureNotes, the pricing for tools is a somewhat big investment. LectureNotes lets you get all the features with just 1 payment while this makes you pay separately for tools, pdf import, cloud, etc.

Overall, It's a pretty efficient note taking app. Lots of colors for ink/ highlighting options, import pdfs/export notes as pdfs (very cool), plus uploading to my google drive. In order to make straight lines or perfect shapes, you have to entirely select a different tool, then switch back to the regular pen. And even then you can only choose between two shapes and straight lines. I wish this were a) more seamless or atleast b) provided more options (like circles instead of just elliptical objects), or parabolas (or even better graph plotting!), or maybe just stars and stuff. But that's really the only complaint I have with it. Everything else is awesome.

The best writing app among samsung notes, one note (free android version) simply because I can set page size and organize my notes well.   UPDATE: After using this app for almost 2 years now, I must say that this is still my app of choice for taking notes in school. Nice colors, for smooth writing and prints fantastically. The biggest problem with other apps is their inability to provide a straightforward way to get notes into PDF properly for printing purposes. Squid is the way to go for taking notes in school, writing assignments and printing.  Only thing I would change in this app is a way to save my notes to the SD card. After almost 2 years, I am running out of space on the pre-installed storage. Also, the lack of a way to export an entire notebook means that I have to manually export each note as PDF to copy that notebook to my long-term storage. That is very tedious but looks like I have no other way to save my notes and free-up space.  My advice for newbies is to export your notes daily or weekly and at the end of a semester delete the notebook to save space. You will thank me later.  Thank the developers for a very useful note-taking app.

Excellent app for capturing my handwriting! I use it on a Chromebook Pro, and it's even smoother than writing on paper. I'm able to easily organize my notes into notebooks, add pages to my notes, and even change whether I'm writing with notebook paper lines, graph paper, or plane white. And did I mention you can change the colors and thickness of the ink? Now, I'm not a fan of subscribing to things - the freemium version of Squid will do almost everything you need for notetaking, and I'm very happy with it. I did some in-app purchases for typing on the screen and adding shapes, and those have been worthwhile and affordable. --- Update: I now also have the app on my phone, and alas there is no way to sync the notes from my phone and my Chromebook. However, both my phone and Chromebook automatically backup my notes to Dropbox every day as PDF's, and it's easy to export the really important notes to specific folders in my Google Drive (and other online platforms) as needed. Plus you can't beat the control for line thickness, color, and page background. Granted, you get even better backgrounds (including daily planner) if you sign up for premium, and I can't afford that. But with a few in-app purchases you can get PDF and JPG import, which will them provide any background you could possibly want. I actually use the app to take photos and then draw sketches over the photos. Once the sketch is done, I copy the lines over to a plain white background, and voila - a nice cartoon image. Do if you're looking for a versatile and dependable notes app with automatic backup, I think this may be your best bet.

I thought this was a good program with smooth writing, so I bought it to be able to import pdf's and write on them. I paid the $10 for a yearly subscription.   Yes, it allows you to write on the pdf's, but the refresh is horrible, I imported a 10 page pdf, and the tablet slowly redraws each page when I move between them. Should not have half the screen disappear. No, it's not the tablet. I use One Note by Microsoft, and I have none of these issues. Honestly not worth it.   I would recommend One Note, which is free and writes smoothly (plus you have access to all your notes on the web for free), or Xodo, which lets you highlight pdf's (I imported a 2000 page document, no issues scrolling entire document), also can add text, draw, and more. Going back to that, should have never left. Figured a paid app would be better than a free one, I was wrong. Really would like a refund.

The app turned out better than I expected. Good set of features and nice user interface. Also very stable; it has never crashed in several months. The import PDF is amazing as I can import a scanned document and mark it up. I use this for work and teaching. I got the subscription. Good value.

It is by far the best app for taking notes! Besides the selection of basic tools like pens and highlighters, there is a wide selection of paper backgrounds to choose from, even without the pro version! Pro isn't needed if you are only interested in using various grid or lined paper, but includes a wide selection of math and engineering type or musical note backgrounds. Whats preventing 5 stars? You can't turn the paper nor is there a stylus mode where you can rest your hand on like in other apps. Besides that out of all the apps I've tried, it is the best.

It's a good app, I bought the subscription because of how good it was and how much it helped me. Lots of features. It replaced ONE NOTE for me. It's great as it is but if the developers for some reason see this and want to improve it a little, then I do have a few tiny nit pics. 1st. The selection too is nice but it only selects in a square. On one note you can select in any with weird shake you want. This makes it easier to omit things that would normally be in the square. Add that as an additional feature, just like the eraser. I love what you did with it. On one note, you only had the stroke erase. Which make 0 made it hard to erase little bits. I would love to be able to square select and free select. Both are useful 2nd. Additional folders. One note didn't have this and to my knowledge this doesn't really either. Just like one sub folder I think. 3rd. PDF export view. This feature would capture the screen or maybe a selection and export a PDF. Would be very nice. I do a lot of math on this and I would like to export my one equation to ask a teacher. Currently I have to copy, open a new page, paste and then export. I do not expect these to ever come to be real but if they do, Great! I have a 4 star because it's a great app. Put one of these features in and I'll meet and it a 5. But I don't that my one additional star means anything to anyone

I've rewritten this review several times now before realizing that google play ui is poorly set up in tablets (the reason for my losing my review writing progress several times) so now I'm writing it elsewhere and pasting it in later. Anyway, I've been compiling a list of features I want from Squid, in a Squid note (for irony or something). But for this review, I'd like to suggest that the devs of Squid try downloading INKredible, the leading competitor for handwritten notes (on Android at least; idk for iOS). There are a lot of similarities and differences, and pros and cons for each, but ultimately I chose to keep Squid. It wasn't an easy choice though, and I hope for Squid to improve to a point where it /would/ be an easy choice. That is, for Squid to implement all the "pros" without adding any of the "cons" of its competitor.

It's a little less functional than I'd like it to be, but for free it comes with enough to draw in different colors and thicknesses and embed images. The strokes with the Pixel Pen are pressure sensitive to increase and decrease the thickness too. You have to pay a couple bucks for the rest of the templates, but it's not a bad price for an app. You can increase page size and change the dimensions to that of different paper standards, add lines or grids, and export to pdf, jpeg, or png. You can also add multiple pages to a single note and organize notes into different notebooks. Works with just a finger too! Lastly, (and I like this feature a lot), you can import pdfs. Great for doing homework right on the assignment. Feature request: add layers for additional drawing tools. I gave it an honest shot. While it is a beautiful app, it lacks the basic staples needed for success. No collaboration, no ability to rearrange notes within a notebook, and most importantly, NO SYNC. This is almost laughable! What powerful note taking app doesn't sync? Doing manual backups and restorations is not only archaic, it is a major liability. How easy is it to lose an entire year of work by accidentally resorting an incorrect backup? Come on guys, this is a no brainer. UPDATE: I dropped from three stars to two stars. I have lost numerous documents because of the lack of syncing options. Also, there has been more than enough time for Squid to update their app to allow automatic syncing. While I understand you can set an automatic cloud update, this is still not helpful because you have to manually restore a backup EVERY SINGLE TIME you use a different device. It is ridiculous.

This is a very well app with just only three flaws ... three big flaws ... first the grid/line color should not be blue! Too much blue and it interfere with my eyes when using black or similar ink colors. Second flaw is the way the stroke rendered on my device (Tab S3). It so bad. Please take a look how Inkredible or even OneNote renders the pen strokes. Third is the pressure sensitivity. It's too sensitive like I always need to put little power everytime I want to write. Yes I know I could disable the pressure feature. Please take a look at Bamboo Paper or OneNote for comparison.

pen support on the pixelbook is great, writes much more smoothly than in keep. However, many critical features that could make this the perfect note-taking app for chrome os are missing. For instance, you cannot scroll continuously through pages of pdfs, and you can't have more than one note open at once (for instance, marking up a pdf textbook and taking notes at the same time). The app also does not have access to local files on the computer, although I have read that this is an issue with android apps in chrome os. Squid does not support syncing to other devices or to Google drive. I have also been experiencing some crashing while working on larger notes. Otherwise, out of all the mediocre/broken ways of taking notes and drawing on chrome os that I have tried so far, this is the least mediocre/broken

This is a really outstanding note taking app for android, if not the best. Taking notes with an active pen is really easy and practical. The interface is really nice and simple. Also a fair price for premium options which really are usefull. The fact that pdfs are exported without being splitted into a4 format (or any format for that matter) is really nice, something that can't be done in onenote for example. Some functions, however, could be better. It would be nice to import PDF files within a note so that you can annotate the PDF file (instead of importing PDF pages seperately as a new page). Also, it would also be nice to have some more figures that you can draw besides the line, square and circle (for example, 2d or 3d axis, triangle, arrows, dotted line etc.) and the option of filling a figure with a certain color. Another thing that can be better are the sync options, OneDrive or GoogleDrive are currently not supported for example.

The PDF importing function needs to be more streamlined. Squid should take into account that many of the people using this app (especially, especially the paid version) have many PDFs to import at once. A multi import would be useful, as would a setting for default sorting of the PDF selection menu (instead of being sorted by name). Turning pages in a multi-paged PDF on tablet should also be more streamined. Currently, the button is small and I often tap the page selection button accidentally instead. Other than that, it's a great app.

I recently switched over to digital note taking for college and this app has allowed me to take even better notes than I could by hand. I use the Samsung galaxy Tab A 10.1 with S Pen (which I highly recommend as a cheaper work/school tablet), and the stylus support with button and finger tools allows me to never really worry about switching between tools, as it's all contained in one hand.There would definitely be a benefit if they allowed multiple device syncing, which they don't have yet. Use it forall my notes

I really love this app, it is so helpful for taking notes in my college courses. There are, however, a few features that I wish could be added/modified. It would be nice if you could erase specific areas of something you've written or drawn, instead of erasing everything that I wrote/drew prior to lifting my pen (ex: cursive). I also wish that it were an option to turn handwriting into text and be able to convert it into a Google Doc for easier edits later on. I love handwriting notes because I feel like I can retain the information better, but sometimes, I like the look of typed notes better and I don't always have time to type my notse after writing them. Lastly, it would be really nice to be able to multitask while using the app. I often watch lecture videos and read my electronic textbooks on my Google Pixelbook while taking notes on the screen, and only being able to do one or the other in tablet mode is not very efficient. I would really appreciate it if some of these concerns could be addressed. I think a few adjustments would make this app even more awesome!

Great premium features and a smooth experience at a fair price. Some features could be added to improve user experience, such as the ability to add a page to the middle of a note, instead of having to add the page to the end of a mote and then moving it to where you want it. This can be a hassle when you're dealing with 100+ page PDFs. Also, we should be able to export multiple notes at once. Overall, good app!

Good app, handles the basics nicely. I'm definitely able to use this to get work done and for the most part it stays out of my way. I will mention, since sometimes the devs read these, that I find the UI to be a bit clunky at times. For instance, I am often transfering between different modes (pencil, highlight, etc) and each transfer takes two button presses followed by a menu-clearing action. I really feel like this should be doable in a single action. Additionally, I am often times switching between different colors/thicknesses or have things that I am copying and pasting regularly. Two very useful features would be (a) color/line-thickness presets for both shapes and writing, and (b) a 'palette' where figures I have drawn can be saved for later use. A walk through of (b) would be: i. I draw a figure and decide to save it for later ii. I highlight the figure and touch button 'add-to-palette', adding the highlighted figure. iii. Later, I want to reuse my figure. I select the palette icon which presents a dropdown of thumbnail icons of each figure. iv. I select one figure and it pastes to the screen

The note taking app I've been searching for! This app includes support for PDF markup, pressure-sensitive styli, images, geometry (rectangles, loops & lines), selection tool, infinite canvas, and tons of other options. My only wish was that this also came on the Windows Store so I could view/sync my notes on my computer. The premium version is easily worth five times the price they charge. Notes never become blurry thanks to the vector-based build. It would be nice if it were possible to pin toolbars (like the color and tool picker) open so that changing ink color—or switching between the pen and selection tool—are just one tap away. Such a feature would be fantastic for taking detailed notes during more fast-paced lectures.

I think this app is awesome! I love that it has (1) the option to buy 
outright only the upgrade options you require, (2) the ability to create 
folders for notes (3) the import pdf option (I used that straight away!) 
(4) Saving & exporting WITHOUT re cloud - essential for those of us with 
confidential info, (5) great export options, (7) page sizes that expand in 
any direction you want(7) easy change in colours (8) lots of options to set 
how use gestures & stylus, & (9) fantastically small export file sizes. I 
would have given a 5 star rating if you could (1) choose the default folder 
you could have it open in, (2) have subfolders (3) be able to see the full 
name of a note when in a folder (4) choose to see the notes as a list 
rather than a thumbnail & MOST OF ALL, (5) a textbox where can wrap text & 
adjust the size & shape of the entry. This problem with the textbox going 
off in one line ad infinitum is a fault at needs to be corrected. 
Otherwise, my team have all chosen Squid as their default work tool to take 
clinical notes with clients in the field using their Samsung Note8 phones. 
If the textbox issue was fixed, the app would be perfect for our needs! 
Thanks for having the best option available.

Squid is the only non Google app that seems to be optimised for the stylus

I tried lots of different Handwriting programs. Squid was not my first 
choice, but it did a few things better than all the others. The main thing 
was that it worked tolerably at a high resolution on my tablet. Others were 
far too slow to work at my top resolution. The second thing that it did was 
that I could import and export PDF's. Other programs had other features 
that I wanted, but did not need. For example, Squid did not zoom, but that 
really did not matter because I did not need it. Still others handled 
drawings better or had more robust file management, but these were usually 
coupled with intolerably slow Handwriting rendering. Squid had the features 
that I needed and worked fine at high resolution. I have used Squid as my 
Handwriting program for several months and I have grown to like it quite a 
bit over time. There are many improvements I could suggest, but nothing I 
suggest would matter over what it already does and does well.

expand my reach as an educator (woe be unto my students). Also, couple this 
with a document scaning app, and now you can scan/import meeting handouts, 
add notes/write over them, and squid will save it as 1 file. It is a great 
way to actually digitize meeting notes and keep your office from getting 
over cluttered with handouts. As a note taking app, the writing reconition 
is very good (just set your s pen button to the eraser); however, I have 
not tried out using pressure sensitivity to adjust writing thickness.

with was the worst.

university classes are very fast paced and profs don't wait for anyone. One 
suggestion would be to have the option to flatten the document as you 
import it onto the app. I personally don't care to have my pages be

the default. Please address this issue this app is extremely helpful 
otherwise.

On my Samsung Galaxy Note 4, which has a resolution of 2560x1440 and a Super AMOLED display, I use the "Squid - Take Notes & Markup PDFs" writing app from the Google play store. And I must say, the writing experience is the closest thing to actually using pencil/pen on paper of a number of popular apps I tested; even better then Samsung's own S Note. The Squid app, which used to be called Papyrus, has near zero latency when writing or drawing. And when comparing Squid to other apps such as Autodesk SketchBook and Wacom's Bamboo Paper on my Note 4, Squid wins hands down. The latency in the other apps is very noticeable, when coming from a Squid writing/drawing session. I use a Staedtler Noris Digital Samsung Pencil, which is sold on Amazon for $19.99.

I recently got a Samsung Chromebook Pro for school, and I absolutely LOVE taking notes with this app.  I can have separate notebooks for all my different classes, I can use their infinite pages to fit an entire lecture's notes on a single page, making it really easy to find the notes from a specific day.  I'm pretty sure my classmates are all really grateful that I can easily turn my notes into a pdf that I can email to them too.  Lots of customization in how the pen works (I've found that 0.3 without pressure sensitivity works best for me).  I love the zoom feature.  It's really nice when you want to write small notes about something but you don't want to take up a whole line. I paid the few extra bucks for the "premium" upgrade, which if I remember correctly included the highlighter option, which is quite nice as well.  The premium package also has a bunch of other page templates like graph paper and stuff which I'll probably never use, but I'm sure would be super handy for someone else.  Honestly, I think my only complaints is that the highlighter doesn't look right... but that could just be that I haven't played around with the settings enough.  I've also had a couple crashes, but I've never lost anything and it's pretty rare and doesn't even take long to restart the app. I definitely recommend this app if you have a tablet with a stylus.  EDIT:  I can't believe I forgot to mention my absolute favorite feature!  THE UNDO BUTTON! I use it so often that I've actually found myself reaching for it when I make a mistake on actual paper!  The eraser is really nice too because it can get rid of an entire penstroke at once (though you can swap so that it only erases what you want too).  And I use the lasso tool a ton when I want to move things around, or copy and paste diagrams and stuff.  Honestly, I love how clean I can make my notes with this app (and how easy it is to do so)!

HOWEVER, developers, it's been a very long time already since u first came out, it's time u add these feature already: Please, augment the pen selection - now there is only 1 pen style. Most every other similar app has that. The color match feature is so critical that you're missing. The writing needs to be smoother as well. Right now it is very choppy, perhaps because it is vector based. Also, subfolder/directory ability, to be able to organize better.   02/14/18  Update I think it's time you integrate these critical things I've asked for for months. I liked trying this app out a lot. It worked very well with my Samsung Chromebook Pro as an Android app. My handwriting wasn't what I hoped it would be, and I struggle with the keyboard on the back of the Pro, but I think it would improve with use of the app. Unfortunately, the author wants a monthly ongoing fee for the app, or you use the "basic" edition. This would be a great $4 or even $5 app - but they want $1/mo or $10/year. In its basic form, there are other great apps that do as well, if not better, and are also free. The free version is fine, but again, so are others that have features this one charges for. (You can pay to upgrade individual add ons like PDF import and eraser tools, but that is more than the app is worth.)
I wish it had Google Drive backup so I can keep the same notes on my Chromebook and my phone

This is almost a great app with a few frustrating flaws. First, its really great to have an app that allows you to draw and "paint" right over PDF's. I use this for marking up landscape drawings with edits for the drafting team. I also use it for responding to questions from contractors. In this, it works well - it's very well synced with dropbox, Google Drive, and any other way you like to share. A few simple problems, however, are VERY frustrating. 1. From my experience and research, you cannot erase part of highlighted areas (which I used frequently). It is an all or nothing delete. 2.  With no confirmation for closing a file, I sometimes bump the back button and the file closes. Auto saving keeps me from losing the file, but I also lose the option for undoing. Not huge, but definitely frustrating. Add a confirmation screen for exiting and the problem is gone. More to come...

This is quite possibly the best "note-taking" app I've ever used.. but it's so much more than that.   It's a very powerful vector drawing tool, with an extremely simple but powerful interface. If you have some text you've hand-written, you can then go and select parts of it, then change the size, or the color, or the brush stroke thickness, or even duplicate it several times then slightly modify each one, rather than having to write something from scratch several times.   And since it's vector-based rather than rasterised, there's no quality loss to writing/drawing something at one size, and then later resizing it, or dragging it around the place, etc. <3  Basically, it's a really fantastic app. I'm very happy that I stumbled upon it however many years ago when I first got a tablet with a built-in stylus, and it has served me well ever since.    Probably the one feature that it's """missing""" (and I say that in the sense that I have absolutely no expectation of it being a feature) would be being able to choose custom typefaces / write with a monospaced font (and beyond that, being able to write syntax-highlighted code....) -- it's a very specific use-case :)

I love this app because I'm always taking notes during class or doing homework, and It works great with the s pen. However I would like some features added. The first feature would be to have folders within the note books. For example have a circuits note book and some folders in there, one for class notes, one for homework, and one for practice. This would greatly enhance the app and would definitely make it 5/5.  Another feature that I would love to see is to have a "night mode" where the background is black and the lines in the paper white so it's easier to write and not shed too much light in the room if it's during a presentation with the lights turned off.  Another feature I would love to see would be top add different backgrounds. Finally I would love to have the option to add pages in a pdf, not just at the end but between pages so I can take more explicit notes.  All this features would make this app be on top for a long time.  However, even without them this app is amazing.

I would give squid 5 stars because it  does serve as an incredible platform to use handwriting on touchscreen devices. However this app could use some minor tweeks to make it comparable to platforms like evernote.  If the creators of squid do not intend to make this app to wholesome, by updating the app to add features such as typing word documents and organizational tools like sub-folders. Squid should expect that users will want to  combine their notes with the other material on a platform that provides these details. The app does allow for exporting or backing up documents using drop-box or box, but there is no easy way to quickly upload to other platforms like onedrive or the google cloud.   This app is great if you're just trying to jot down some stuff on a touchscreen device. However if you intend to use it as your primary tool for school or work, the app needs some help before it can provide as a good platform for all of your work.

Paid user here. This app has so much potential and is so useful, but it is hurt by a few key problems. If the following could be fixed, it would be one of the best apps on the Play Store:  1 - Please add continuous scroll for PDFs, like in Adobe Reader / Foxit.  2 - If you add continuous scroll, please allow PDFs to still be editable in continuous scroll! 3 - Please allow default widths to be applicable to imported pdfs, whether in portrait or landscape; it's a huge pain to have to continuously zoom in or out for every page of a document I'm reading / scrolling through.  4 - Please enable full screen with no toolbar up top; maybe a single finger tap could call up or hide the toolbar, like in many other apps? 5 - please enable inverted dark theme for text / white background! For example, if I'm reading and annotating a screenplay, especially at night or on an AMOLED display, it would be great to be able to make the white PDF background black.   I've been hopping between Squid and Adobe Reader on my tablet because both apps do half of what I need. If squid could add the above, it would be great and I would keep paying for it.

Best note taking app that supports the active pen. Premium purchases are worth it. Much easier to use then LectureNotes, but not as customizable. There is no latency in regards to pen input. The pen chooser is quick and intuitive, but there is room for improvement. I purchased all the premium features and among them my favorites are the highlighter and PDF import. Premium paper patterns are only available as a subscription service. The cloud backup (also premium) implements Dropbox or Box as the backup service, which works fairly well as a backup tool. However, I would like a cloud sync feature (like Dropbox on the PC or like Google Drive) so that my notes automatically sync across devices. Right now, it works more like a backup service then a sync service even though it uses Dropbox. Your changes on one device will not sync to the other device, you have to do this manually by restoring from a backup and saving a backup.

I use my tablet for note taking for university and used it during a levels. In the past I gave this app a 5 star review saying all it needed was a writing input zone (something I know many many other users would agree with). I am extremely disappointed to see it still hasn't been added as a feature, especially as users have been requesting it for such a long time. It would make writing in this app much much much easier. Something like what lecture notes and notability have in this regards would go a long way. Also having endless scrolling for your pages (again like lecture notes and notability) rather than having to press between pages would be nice as well as it would be quicker to check past lines of works when doing long equations and such. Add these two features (preferably as one time pay features seeing as they feel like key features to every other good writing app) and this review would instantly be changed to five stars.

If anybody finds this to be in bad taste, I will change it to a 5 star to reflect my actual opinion of the app. First a quick review. This app is fantastic. I use it for taking notes in university. I use it to jot down video game ideas. I use it to doodle when I'm not paying attention to a lecture.  The free version is everything you need to take sufficient notes although I've payed for a few tools to enhance the experience; well worth it. If i had ONE wish, it would be that notes would have tags and be searchable by the tags so that we could search for notes by the content. Titles just aren't enough for me to remember everything the notes contain.   Adding compatibility with multi-window on galaxy tablets would be awesome too so that I could read a pdf textbook and take notes simultaneously. Anyway, thanks for saving me from wasting paper and pencils and erasers. Keep up the good work.

Great little app & helpful / communicative developer.  Been using the Premium (though NON subscription) version of this app for about 8 months now.  It's generally been great!  The only things that have been a little tedious is that the Cloud based sync using Box can be a little on the slow side when you have an increasing number of files .   Also when you have a large ongoing ("infinity") sized document, strolling can be a little on the slower side as the document when fully sized & takes a few moments to get reconfigured / repopulate with each swipe. With the kind of docs I create, that can delay things when editing & looking for a section.  Some people have expressed concern about the subscription model being 'enforced' on them. Personally I don't have a problem with developers going subscription & would have upgraded to it if it offered more features than simply a few paper styles that I didn't really have a need for or if I didn't already purchase all the Premium add ons.  But as I purchased all the Premium add ons separately last year (which I believe is / was still an option now ), I didn't yet see the value in going subscription. Time will tell if this changes.

I uninstalled and reinstalled squid and found that all of my notes are gone! No Warning on uninstall that all of my notes would be erased. Is this really true? On is there away to recover my notes?... I was finally able to restore my subscription after losing all paid features for several months. It turns out that Squid could not tell that I was the main software user. It thought that my son's account was the main software user. Not clear on how it got confused. Never the less, after removing my son's account from my tablet, and after uninstalling and reinstalling the software, I was able to use paid for features. But the final burn... After restoring my notes from cloud backup, I lost all of my notes from since 5-Dec of last year. It seems that Squid broke my backups during the move from what it was formaly, "Papyrus". Although I love the features, given the huge loss of data... I give only 1 star. I wish better luck for others.

However there are a few features I'd really like to see. One is when importing pictures into a note, you can't import only parts of PDFs. Another is when exporting my notes to pdf, they aren't sized very well for printing, although they're fine digitally viewing because I can zoom. Lastly i would like a print view or a preview of a normal paper boundary, like if I wanted to write only within the bounds of an 8.5x11 paper. Other than that it is great.

UPDATE: Since upgrading my tablet, I have had zero problems with this app. Using it to take notes in class has made it possible for me to succeed in college.  I really liked the idea of being able to write with my finger on a tablet, as I have a condition that makes gripping a pencil very difficult. However, Papyrus randomly closes the note I'm working on and returns to the home screen without saving my work. I lose work, sometimes a lot. An auto-save feature would be nice, so the note would save itself every certain number of minutes. They should fix this random closing issue. It's making me want to find another notetaking program.  Also, when .pdfs are exported, small objects like periods get lost in the process. When working on math problems, decimals are always omitted during .pdf export.

In fact they've posted a long article online trying to rationalize their feeling of entitlement... It reminds me of McDonalds workers who complain that they can't raise a family on the salary they're being paid.  Save yourself the coin and frustration and just buy Lecture Notes. It's a much more polished app, is extremely mature and reliable, and they understand what their product's worth! Buy it once and use it forever, including updates. None of this subscription crap!

Fantastic app.  I was disappointed to see the removal of the former app Papyrus but the features of the revised app are definite improvements.  A must for any Samsung Note device.  PDF support is a great addition.  The option to turn on/off the pressure sensitivity for Samsung S-Pen is helpful if you find the pressure sensitivity of the Note 5 an issue.  I was able to take a few pictures of products on my Note 5, bring the pictures into a note then draw a few comments on the pictures and type / write some additional comments, PDF the entire note and email (or text it) to a few people.  It may not have the organizational abilities of OneNote or Evernote, but it writes smoothly on Note devices and you can incorporate pictures and PDFs into an endless paper where you cannot do this as easily in other apps.

Update 12/15/2015: Since I use this for work, a functioning backup is critical. Unfortunately, the automatic backup and pdf functions ("premium" features for which I have paid) no longer work once you have accumulated a decent number of notes. Several fixes to this problem have been suggested by users on the Squid feedback website - such as incremental backups - but there is no indication of a plan to implement any solution.  So, if you just want to use it for a few doodles, it's great. But if you actually want something that you can count on, look somewhere else until they fix this issue.   Original: Still needs a few features to be added, but they seem to be pretty responsive to user input - so I expect to see those things implemented eventually.

As far as features, it's as straightforward as an actual paper notebook. Open the app, create a notebook, and start writing smoothly and quickly. Erasing, and changing pen color on the fly is neat, as well as the ability to choose stationary (blank, college ruled, wide ruled, etc) per your preference. It truly is an electronic notepad.   Though, it slightly falls short of the accuracy found in apps like Evernote or Handrite Note, lacking the ability to compensate for stroke imperfections to keep what you write looking as close to your actual handwriting as possible. This irks me, but it probably won't bother most.

Along that same theme....  2) Export Notebooks/Batch export - as it is right now I have to open the note, open the menu and export for every single note.  I really wish I could long press on a note/notes and export, as well as being able to long press on a notebook title and export.  3) Sub-notebook/folder organization -as I said, I use this for all my classes, which means I have a notebook for each class, but I've subdivided them further into notes folders for each class, homework folders for each class, as well as personal projects, to do lists, grocery list, sketches, etc.... I have tried several handwritting note apps, and Squid ((formerly Papyrus) is the best out of the bunch.   I like Squid better then the in-built S-Note. (If you are using Note 8, you can download the improve S-Note).   Other handwritting Apps each have their strenghts and weaknesses, but for me Squid  stands out from the best. I    hope they do improve the software. For instance, I like INKredible which wins out on the smoothness of its handwritting and the background template.       Wishlist:   1. Page template e.,g. Diary Template (similar to INKredible)  2. Ability to copy from Samsung clipboard (ie. to select from web site and paste)  3. Smooth handwritting  4. Tool Pallette easily available rather then going into a sub-menu. 5. I choose the A4 papersize. However, when you zoom-in-out. It changes  your choose papersize from A4 to infinite, which is very naughty. 6. I can't insert a page before page one. 8. Everything I add a new page, I have to keep changing the page setting e.g. size to A4 and blank page. Why can't it default to what I want?. 9. Add image, give you lots of ways to add an image, but wish there was a dedicated 'add image from camera'.

This app is a minimalist alternative to apps like Evernote or OneNote. Sometimes you just want to write something down quickly without navigating through multiple screens, logging into an account or generating a unique format document like a checklist. Papyrus came close but it wasn't as sleek and the pages were hard to keep sized correctly. This redesign, complete with the coolest logo ever, make me smile. I hope Squid doesn't try to compete with other note apps by adding more and more distracting features over time. This app is worth way more than it's premium package price in its current state.

If you've changed your DPI settings, the handwriting and eraser effects will apply inches away from where the actual tip of your stylus is. Evernote, OneNote, Smart Note, Sketchbook,  and Quill do not have this limitation. If you could make your app respect user defined DPI settings it'd be worth 5 stars because it really does work well.

I would like it to work more easily with text,  being able to copy text and edit it in my notes. I would also like an easier way to copy pictures into my notes.  For example using my spen I can easily grab part of my screen,  but to put it into a note I first have to save it as a bitmap file and then import it into squid. Finally,  there should be an option to post-process the images captured by the camera in the way that camera scanner does. The contrast is increased so that the text of the picture of a paper note has maximum visibility on the screen.

Background: I came from IOS on an ipad mini and iphone, this app replaced Notability... Almost.   The Good: Drawing features are excellent. Love the touch sensitivity built into the stylus of the note. Differentiating stylus input from finger input is so great. I can draw with the stylus, and if needed, zoom in with my fingers, draw a marquee around an object it with my finger to select it, and then scale, copy, move or delete with no tool chagning. I bought all the add-on's after the free trial period without even hesitating. They're all  extremely useful. Although, to be fair, a little expensive. In most cases, it's easy to manipulate images from other apps through sharing and/or opening into squid/papyrus.    The Bad: Editing text... aweful. Some bugginess on the widgets loosing their names in a folder for shortcuts and infinite screen size creates issues where the screen stops recognizing finger inputs at the system level, not application level. The backup features NEEDS to be able to use the same file on multiple devices.   I would replace this with notibility if I could for the improved text, backup, and cloud features.

This app is really useful and has some great features that I have put to use while note-taking and studying. However, there is an issue with the responsiveness of the touchscreen that occurs intermittently on my tablet, where it will stop recognizing my finger when I try to erase strokes. I have dealt with this by turning off and back on the display, which will fix the problem for a while. I have also noticed that the S Pen will occasionally write things about a centimeter away from the point where the pen is applied on-screen. I'm not sure if these problems are due to my tablet or the application, but other than that, this app is highly recommendable.   One suggestion for future development could be to include a feature where automatic syncing to the cloud is done only to files that have been updated/ written on since the last synchronization (instead of uploading all files to the cloud each time).

Anyone that gives this less than 5 stars is either uninformed or unreasonable. It's vector graphics - there are limitations which the app provides for. Has a combo of features that are surprisingly difficult to find - highlight and take notes on the document, then save as the original document on my device so I don't have to go looking for it. What could be improved?  It needs an easier way to zoom the pages, like a default zoom level you can select for the document. Also, the default edit setting shouldn't be a writing tool. I should have to select when I want a screen press to write something. Default should be one-finger moves the page. It needs a quick page select feature at the bottom of the screen as well as a little indicator telling me I'm on page x of xx. Lastly, an intelligent highlight assist is needed - other apps sense the line of text and keep you on it, while Papyrus essentially has a draw function requiring impeccable accuracy to highlight.

This app is simple yet powerful. The infinite page size (which I'm still almost infinitely less than using completely) let's me not stop mid thought to add a page or move text over. The lasso (copy/paste) tool is scarily good at moving only what I want (gets entire shapes/letters without bordering shapes/letters or cutting in half), and for resizing. I'm assuming it uses vectors but whatever it is makes resizing selections stay just as clear and sharp. And unlike other apps it doesn't have any pause between drawing and seeing it on the screen. I used lecture notes before this and loved it except for the speed (even using all the tweaks the author suggested). And I didn't know infinite page size was a possibility. The only thing I can think of wanting is more shapes, like an arrow. But that's easy to just draw and copy/paste.

This app lost me hundreds of dollars, and, except for my keenness of mind, could have ended in the death of myself. I used this app for mission-critical, real-time note-taking for medication and dosage management, since it was the only one with support for the stylus on the Note 3 and skeumorphic paper. The app glitched and deleted three days worth of notes (which are lists of numbers for me, including times and dosages), and replaced them with no warning with notes from three days ago. If I had trusted the app and not had the intuition that 'these numbers are wrong', harm could have resulted. LESSON: NEVER USE NON-CERTIFIED 'CONSUMER'-GRADE TRASH FOR MISSION-CRITICAL APPLICATIONS.  Negative ten, and the first review I have ever posted -- and ever intend to. I've never had an app that nearly let me die before. It's like a anaesthesia timer that counts two minutes per minute.

I bulk installed around 10 similar apps looking for something like this. Nothing offers such a well design app for note taking. This is the only one left installed. Operation is learnt in about 5 mins.  No nonsense design means you can open new or add to existing organised notes or notebooks with very few selections.  I'm using it in the context of an IT support department so I need to get going in the time it takes to pick the phone up and say 'hello'.  Writing tools are easily changable as you go with 'extras' little more than the cost of a similar paper notepad. Editing facilities are excellent with erasing / box drag select sections.  When done notes can be sent to the cloud in a couple of taps to access from anywhere to whoever selected.

This is an excellent app - in that it provides good features and executes them beautifully. Features = import bookmarks and annotate them in all ways; make free-form notes and notebooks; export all kinds of note-documents into PDF;  Save; and then Share them via email or adding to Dropbox.   The feature I feel is missing is "automatic syncing to Dropbox" -- I find it so many times that I want to access my docs somewhere, and have not explicitly Exported them. There needs to be a way to control this feature - basically, I want to designate a document to be always sync'd to Dropbox by default. That is, the "Save" command should function as Sync. Also, it should remember where in my Dropbox folder structure the document should go.

Having now tried pretty much every 3+ star rated handwritten note-style app in the marketplace, I can confidently say that this is the best one by a LONG shot.  To be clear, I use a Galaxy Note 10.1 - and with that form factor in mind (i.e., an active pen), it's fantastic for note taking.  It also works very well as an ebook - provided you load them in as PDFs.  It could use some features to round out its usability - but I mean this in the sense of MS Office needing improvements, not NeoOffice - that is to say: the tool is complete as is and very good, but obviously it's not perfect.  If you're looking for an all-purpose handwriting app, I HIGHLY recommend getting it.

Without the toolkit you can erase with your finger, but only full strokes...

Nice app but has functionality limitations that make it a no-go for me: * The toolbar isn't permanently visible, so it takes several clicks to switch between the various tools. Gets really clunky when you need to switch regularly. * No scroll by swiping, and no continuous page display  * Page navigation is done by either hitting the forward or back key , or pressing the page number and spinning through all the pages - takes forever on a large document  * Phone app freezes on large PDFs  *Zoom level doesn't hold when you change pages  * Pasting text from other apps doesn't wrap the text - just sticks it in as one long line Lecturenotes has a bigger learning curve but provides all of this and lots more, so I've adopted that as may primary note taking app.

Thankfully I came across Papyrus.  From that point on I've put my complete trust in this app. The backup features are seamless. It's easy to use. Exactly what I need.

I use Papyrus on my Samsung 12.2 pro for mindmapping. The "infinite" paper setting allows you to map ideas without limit, zooming in and out as you need. Great for taking interview notes as you never have to find another piece of paper. Then send to pdf, print and off you go. I love writing with the stylus and erasing with my finger! A few more tricks that other software has got (smarter page turning, thumbnails to scan for the right page, and saved pen pre-sets, bookmark tabs) would be great additions and then it would outclass any rivals for journal writers.

I use Papyrus to take notes during meetings and, increasingly, in place of paper notes while working on design problems. I'll then often use it to compose better organized, more readable versions of those notes to share with team members.  It's almost as transparent a tool for recording thoughts as pen and paper but can be easily backed up with all the other digital assets that go with a project as well as duplicated and shared with others.  Being vector based makes the notes much more editable and a higher visual quality than those created by Samsung's S-Note.  My only problem at this point is that the number of notes I've created is adding up and the tools for organizing them aren't as powerful as I'd prefer. Notes can be organized into notebooks but the ability to nest those groupings or tag notes for sorting and filtering would help a lot for some of my larger projects.

This is a very nice note-taking app that is easy to use. Sadly, it is sorely lacking in basic features such as moving or even deleting pages in a notebook, giving titles to pages, etc. It actually feels like the whole idea of "notebooks" was an afterthought. To make matters worse, it seems the devs are not longer actively supporting this app. "In development" features on their website sit unimplemented for years with not so much as a word from the devs. So the app was nice for its day, but it has become obsolete.

The folder view has an image of the 1st page, which makes it very easy to find what you are looking for.  Negatives : No way to insert a blank page!! when switching back to the writing/ pen tool, from say the selection tool it brings up the pen options dialog, which has to be dismissed before you can start writing again. Wider cloud support would be good. Changing the behavior of some actions didn't work ; it would be nice if the pen right click allowed you to select objects (ala OneNote). Can't import vector graphic files like eps or svg, so images (in particular plots from say Matlab) don't look great, but is usable.

Papyrus is a great experience if you're only looking at the free version. I love the two finger scroll and zoom and single finger erase functions - they make note taking so much more streamlined and easy to use! I love how zooming in doesn't fuzz up the writing, which is something I had a serious issue with in LectureNotes. The only problem with Papyrus is that its extra features aren't even that great, and are definitely not worth the price especially when compared to other note taking apps in the market. I also wish there was an audio recording function, because taking notes to a professor speaking is a great tool to have. When other apps in the market have this capability, and at a much lower price than what Papyrus currently offers even without this capability, you know that there needs to be some fixing. I'm definitely regretting purchasing these premium features, and would refund if possible. I love taking plain notes on Papyrus though, and that will keep me using the app for future use.

The whole point of a pdf import, for me at least, was to be able to markup a pdf already on my tablet, so when my tablet syncs with my office network, the file backs up and replaces the older file in the office network. Importing the pdf creates a new file within Papyrus that has no relation to the original. To actually use the markups, I need to pay even more for the cloud storage, which only syncs with Box and Dropbox (and from what I see in the reviews, that's not working all that well either.) So then I'd have to make the cloud version sync with the office version, and then sync that with my tablet. Way too much file duplication to bother with.   Now, if I could use Papyrus's tools to markup an existing pdf without the need to import it and create a new note, then that would be very nice. Otherwise, it leaves me feeling that the developers were being short sighted, greedy, and selfish, forcing us to pay to use the pdf function, and then forcing us to pay to actually do anything with the documents after Papyrus gets a hold of it.
I wish there was the ability to type notes (it will type short notes) instead of handwriting all the time.  But overall Excellent at its job.

This app had the potential to be a really great tool for note taking.  However, after purchasing the premium shapes and text addon, I was very surprised at just how basic these 'premium' features were!  The text tool doesn't support wrapping - a bare minimum when you are writing text onto a page.  Text is also entered into a separate edit window instead of directly onto the page.  Shape drawing doesn't even support filled shapes!  The app also doesn't support any form of transparency for items that are drawn.  So you can't use a pen as a highlighter for example.  Lots of things that should improve just to say that it supports basic features.
Coupled with a Samsung Note 8, Papyrus has taken over my note writing, from meetings to working as a lab notebook.  Highly recommended.

Makes good use of the S pen API.  And probably the only app that feels closest to natural writing on paper.  I don't like zoom boxes or zooming in general when I write.  I prefer zoom locking so I have some idea of how large or small my hand writing is.  I love the page size limits so i know when i reach the edge of a page and need to get a new page.  This is a must for making printouts of my notes.  Also I have a tendency to rest my wrist on the device as if it was paper and it doesn't activate other functions like zoom or starts using my wrist to continue writing.  I love this feature the best because I don't need to suspend my wrist and write in this unnatural unergonomic manner.  I don't know  about other people, writing with my wrist suspended causes me physical pain so this is the only usable note taking app I can use without hurting my wrist. I wish an iOS version of this existed and some how had the same ergonomic feature as this. The only drawback is that there is no option to delete pages within the notes.  And other minir features like moving and inserting pages would be nice, but if I could at least delete pages, even as a premium feature I would buy.

Update: The newest update of the app finally brings the ability to import PDFs and mark them up as you see fit... as a premium feature in which you have to pay for in order to utilize. This wouldn't be a big deal if it were a similar price to the other two features ($2 at the time I purchased them),  but for so reason,  the developers thought that a feature that comes standard in several other note takings apps was worth their customers paying an additional $5 for it. Papyrus may have the edge when it comes to how well it writes, but it definitely costs a hefty price ($9 if you want all of the features). 2 stars.   Original review: This is a great app overall. Improvements such as the ability to import/edit PDF files would make this leaps and bounds better than other competing note taking applications. Very responsive when writing with a stylus.   Another huge gripe that I have with the existing version of  Papyrus is the lack of S-Pen functionality. Yes,  I know that the developer claims that Samsung has prevented third-party developers from utilizing S-Pen button actions,  but I have seen other third party applications make use of it,  so forgive me if I'm not entirely convinced.

I have found the Papyrus app better for my journal writing than the S-note app that comes with my Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 tablet. Papyrus allows setting the page size to 8.5x11. With the tablet in landscape orientation, the 8.5" width of the screen means I can write in the same scale as on standard paper with a traditional pen. The app also provides a greater range of pen line widths, has better pressure sensitivity, and it's a vector program that exports a much sharper page to PDF than the S-note's jpeg-based export. Print-outs look very much like my old hand-written pages. Also, Papyrus PDF pages can be opened in Adobe Illustrator for more advanced editing of the vector-based lines if desired.

Papyrus may not be as feature rich as the S Note app version that originally shipped with my Note 2 and Note 10.1 2012 but...and apologies for the Samsung rant...  Since my Note 2 updated to Android 4.3, the new version of S Note (with less features, and new file format I can't use on my Note 10.1 2012), and the Samsung cloud features which no longer reliably support the inter device syncing I rely on are corrupting my note files (feels like a cynical move by Samsung to force me to buy new hardware or maybe just a really really badly planned rollout). I therefore decided to look for an alternative that didn't tie me to Samsung software or a never materialising Android upgrade for my Note 10.1 2012 (love their hardware but can't trust their abilities to reliably provide compatible software for a tablet I have only owned for 9 months)  Papyrus is absolutely that alternative. The pen tracking is way better than S Note. S Note always was a tiny bit off. What appeared on the screen was never exactly aligned with the S Pen nib. With Papyrus it is so spot on and faster too. When combined with the exceptional pressure sensing using Papyrus is like writing with pencil and paper. Superb.

I'd like to give this 5 stars as I really do use Papyrus a lot (much better than SNote in many ways!). Otherwise, keep up the good work! :)

I'm using a Nexus 10 with passive stylus.    This app works ok.  But if you've used Notability for iPad, you will be dissapointed.  Here are some features I would like to see to make this a better app:  The response is slow relative to my ability to write.  This also has the side effect of making the written letters look smaller than the hand motion would have dictated.  Doesn't allow typing in the non-premium version.  Screen does not auto adjust as you move to the edge while writing.  You have to stop what you are doing and manually scroll the page.  There is no highlighter.  Page settings are limited -- no background color change??  No search or OCR support.  I have to zoom the entire page to make a space large enough to write on (Can't write very small with a stylus.) .  So I can only see a tiny bit of my page while I'm writing.    Given the limitations. particularly in the pen response, I'm not motivated to buy the premium version.

Being that I have not opted for the premium services yet, I'm giving this application a 5 because my I can overlook a couple things I would have liked to have seen.  I like that the application is simple, runs fairly well, and takes up relatively little space.  The backgrounds are classic and not overdone at all; it is very practical (a major plus) being that it is quite reminiscent of writing on actual paper.  It is perfect for anyone who only wants a notepad!  There are only a couple things I would have liked to have seen, though of course, not at all critical:  *Logarithmic paper (just in case). *Something (perhaps at the main page) that tells me the total pages that have writing or are being used by each note. *A way to insert a page between pages. *An option to list each note/notebook as a list instead of tiles so that it may be easier to navigate a large number of them.  Overall, the app is very functional and I use it all the time for just about everything.

Papyrus is an amazing notetaking app. Instant erase and undo/redo with one touch. You can transition from pen to finger to erase in a split second. Almost all other note apps require a tool change for this function. I can't even begin to describe how much faster this makes Papyrus compared to everything else.   The page layouts are minimalist and simple. Controls are intuitive and sparse. This is a notetaking app. We don't need all that extra BS. You can either see an overview at a glance, or scroll through the pages one at a time. The interface is blazingly fast to navigate! The notes simply save when you move to another page or quit. No time wasting prompts, no hand holding       My only complaint is that the pen isn't as responsive and quick as the Autodesk Sketchbook App. It may have something to do with these types of apps vectorizing the writing, rather than the raster ouput in Sketchbook.    Otherwise, this is easily the greatest note-taking app available for Android.

OK, two complaints: I'd like to be able to copy an entire page so I can modify it, or at least be able to lasso-select the entire contents of a page at once rather than just the limited amount that will fit on the screen. Why isn't Samsung Note tablet native drawing Ul/API this simple and unobtrusive? Two actual usability issues: 1) Even if a note is stored in a folder, recent notes does not show the name of the folder the note is in. Sometimes I move a note in a folder and because of a motoric error it ends up in the wrong folder. Since there is no "sort notes by last moved to folder", it gets really hard to find a note in such situation. 2) Accidental generation of notes: I often press the add new note button without thinking. Then I perhaps leave papyrus on in the background. I end up closing the note at some point but don't remember if I wrote something in it. Then it gets annoying since I need to check if the note has contents - that does not necessarily show in the note icon - before deleting the note, to make sure I don't delete anything that matters. So not saving notes at all before they have any content or their name set would probably be a good idea.  Also, I would like a fill tool. I understand it may go against your philosophy but really, in practice, I often want a coloured canvas to paint on first for example. Or just fill a shape.

The pressure sensitivity of the s-pen doesn't work as well.  Half of the time, the software does not recognize that the pen tip is on the tablet when I am writing.  Also, when it does,  the strokes start of either heavy and then abruptly turn skinny OR vice versa. There isn't a smooth transition even if I smoothly apply pressure or slowly let go of the pressure.  Also, the brush strokes are "twitchy".  I think every s-pen for the samsung note 8 OR the 10.1 version have a little bit of give on the tip -- very, very slight give because of the pressure sensitivity mechanism (I have both s-pen versions) .  When writing on the tablet, this "give' causes the brush strokes to not be smooth; I think the stock samsung software accounts for this and slightly smooths out the strokes making my hand written notes look a lot better and more natural.  However,  the stock software doesn't do copy and paste.  The Papyrus software does and it does it really well.  This is one of the reason why I tried Papyrus.. I hope the author continues to work on Papyrus though.  Even with all the negatives, it is a good program...

it's nicer and much simpler than s-note, but i have some gripes and ideas to improve them, hope the dev reads this:  -custom page layout/more page layout. i really want the lined one with middle page vertical margin for the fixed page sises -multi-notebook/folder -tags/automatic names using date and time -manual magnification (enter the percentages manually) and fixed default xoom (so when add new note/open note, goes to a preset magnification (not 100%)  other than that it's very good, keep up the good work

Papyrus does have the ability to share my notes in an accessible (PC and android) system - like Evernote but only as pdf, jpeg or png.  spoiled by MS OneNote that I used on a PC tablet. I use Papyrus on a daily basis because it is very good. Still I only rate it 2stars because it is still missing the basic functionality that every note taking app has.  For example: it is impossible to see if a note has a next page or not. You just have to try in each note you open to press the next button. If you get a blank page then there was no next page... Gets very annoying after a time. How difficult can it be to just put an indicator like "page 1of 6"?  There is also no way the system remembers your zoom-level. I like to zoom out on a page when I open a note to see all the contents on a page. Then, when going to the next page, it forgets about this and zooms back tot the default. If you quickly want to browse through the pages of a note to look for something, then you have to zoom out or pan on every page of the note. I am getting really tired of this.   The developer seems to be concentrating on adding more advanced features, but forgets about the basics.  The good part of Papyrus is the actual writing. The most fluid and easy to use of all the apps I tried. The fact that you get a nice PDF copy in your dropbox is a killer feature.

This app has finally allowed me to let go of my paper notepads. The combination of Papyrus and The Galaxy Note devices (I have the 2 and the 10) is the first time I've gotten the same tactile feeling from a device as I get from pencil and paper. Add that to the infinite, vector based format of Papyrus notes, the graph or lined backgrounds, cloud storage, the masking tool, color and brush options... You end up with the next evolution in note-taking. The only (tiny) drawback has been the load times for some of my larger notes - the trade off for infinite page space is a few seconds loading it up. This can easily be avoided with proper organization, however. The app is of excellent quality, and I am grateful to the developers for improving the way I work and create.
