Papyrus easily has the best user interface out of all the notetaking apps I've used to date on my ThinkPad Tablet. I've been a heavy OneNote user for years on my Windows machines, and Papyrus is the only thing on Android that can match its freedom of input.  From the point of view of a OneNote user, however, Papyrus still has its problems. First and foremost, it lacks search. Second, it only outputs PDF, JPG and PNG and imports nothing, so you can't switch between devices or collaborate with anyone who doesn't happen to own a pen-enabled Android tablet. Third, its palm rejection and zoom will join forces to make you lose your place in the note.  That said, Papyrus is a dream to use; it's design is leagues ahead of other pen-enabled notetaking apps, especially the dismal Android OneNote client. I only wish that Papyrus was a little more aware of the notetaking world around it.

I use Papyrus at work on my Note II for sketching out ideas, process blueprinting, and writing up mock tutorials. Since the latest update, I can import screen captures from other apps.  Probably the part about Papyrus that sets it apart from other note-taking apps is that you can create infinitely-sized notes simply by two-finger dragging the page to create new space. You have no idea how useful it is to not be restrained by page size when you're working on a small device.  Sometimes my note gets so large after working on it for a while and I start to see where things could be broken down into smaller parts. I would love to see a feature where you could break apart a single page into multiple pages based upon a selection.
Easy and very fast. Replaced any paper book of mine. With an s pen its a must have.

First and only app I have yet found that properly works for taking handwritten notes. Directly supports Wacom-equipped Thinkpads and the pressure//eraser/buttons actually work as expected.  Tiny amount of pen>screen lag, but you get used to it in a minute or two. (and not unexpected as due to dev version of JB-4.22 running on "new" hardware)

I like the true eraser tool, but it should be free with the app. Also, we need to be able to assign the true eraser to the button press on our stylus (right now, it can only be assigned to "single-finger touch". I can't recommend this app until that functionality is added. Lecture notes is a better choice at this moment.

This is my note app of choice - it is the closest thing to a perfect experience that I have found. There only a few things standing in the way of this app being ideal for my needs. It makes lecture notes viable even on the relatively small screen of the note 2. It looks like there is active development of the app, so it should keep getting better. A list of things I found to be nice/not nice: Awesome:  (1) Palm rejection  (2) Infinite page both down and to the side  (3) Can use fingers to resize/move while taking notes  (4) Pressure sensitive to S pen  (5) No tools on bottom of screen  in landscape mode  (6) Can add pictures into note page.    Not-yet-awesome:  (1) S pen side button does not work (not their fault)  (2) No single finger scrolling  (3) Scrolling takes a second to load different parts of a page  (4) Cloud services (in app purchase) does not yet have Google Drive.  (5) Can't save notes to SD card  (6) Writing does not seem as smooth as in S note (S note seems to do smoothing)

Tried almost everything else in the play store, and nothing comes close to this app in terms of quality. I take lot of handwritten notes, and I am quite particular about the stroke quality. Image insert, marker, keyboard input,

a) Export to PDF, JPEG, or PNG for viewing, editing, and sharing on other devices b) Pressure sensitive (S-pen) for fluid writing and hand drawings c) Use multiple tools at once -Draw with stylus -Select with stylus button -Erase with single-finger -Pan/Zoom with double-finger  d) Cut, copy, paste single or multiple selected markings  I use it for writing engineering/physics notes during lecture and I couldnt ask for anything more (we write about 6 pages of 8.5x11 notes in 1 hour lecture). I can quickly draw a design using freehand or line/box/circle tools, adjust thickness/color and add text. Holding the S-pen button, I can quickly select a component (one marking or a group of markings) and resize it and and change color, thickness, etc. Also while selected, you can CUT, COPY, DUPLICATE, and PASTE groups of markings, even between different notes. This amazing feature allows me to select an engineering problem and replicate into a new note, to start a new problem with a similar setup, to expand in detail on that problem, or even make several altered versions of one design with changing the original. This is also great in problem solving, for repeating symbols and equations

My current problem with the app, though, which makes it hard to like it all the way, is that when I'm typing long notes, the app occasionally freezes when I hit the 'done' button and I lose everything I just typed. Only seems to happen with long notes with many lines of text, but that is a huge part of what I use the app for.

Using on my Asus Transformer TF101, and while I know it's old, I have used other handwriting apps (FreeNote) and they are much faster than this.  It is so bad, that a letter does not render until I have nearly finished it when I am writing at normal speed.  This makes it very difficult to write legibly, and to do so, I have to write very slowly.  There are not a lot of configuration options, so I tried making sure there was nothing else loading down the tablet, and I also tried three different styli.  Nothing seemed to help.  It's unfortunate, because I really like the interface, which is my main gripe with FreeNote, but it looks like for now that the devs chose form over function.  When this is optimized, I would consider installing it again.  The form is nice, the function needs work.

Accessing and changing tools and changing basic pen settings are quick because there are  minimal steps to navigate features.  Unfortunately, there is noticeable delay between my stylus input and the appearance of writing strokes.  I don't notice the delay in Quill or Samsung SNote, but I spend time waiting for Papyrus Beta to to register pen strokes.  Though the awesome interface is worth money, I'm reluctant to spend $10 to unlock features if the most basic need, quick and smooth stylus input, is not met.  Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1

Papyrus is an application designed to do but one thing, and do it well: handwritten notes. It uses pressure-sensitive strokes within its own pen-nib framework (NOT using the common S-Pen palette) and stores the strokes in a vector format(‼) so filesizes are incredibly small, even to hundreds of pages per notebook. It doesn't do anything beyond handwritten notes, and users should not consider it a replacement to or competitor of S-Note/S-Memo or comparable all-in-one apps, but rather as a complement to a notation suite. Also, and crucially, this app is free and totally uninfected by ads or crippled features, the single upsell-scheme a discreet Settings mention for cloud-storage integration (and should the ad push ever become more obtrusive I will retract my rating). This is an outstanding application for those with pen devices.

My only difficulty has been the lateral sheet navigation ( when sheet is huge compared to the small portion which is shown on the display). Instead of using 2-fingers, a possible alternative, is to introduce a LABS-type pop-up buttons .... when stickyFinger touches the extreme Left edge or Right edge of display, about 85% down towards the bottom edge. When the LABS button menu pops-up, user can toggle between "simple stylus navigation" or "writing mode". Then, navigation can be done easily with one finger or simply using the passive Stylus pointer. An alternative might also be to add the toggle setting (mentioned above) to the parameters menu ( existing... 3-dot menu) as a 6th item in the list. Thanks for this great App ;

This is still a beta.  An impressive beta.  A useable beta.  But beta nonetheless.  What it offers is a clean interface and a good inking experience.    What sets it apart from other note apps is the great support for active pens.  The availability of customizable gestures is fantastic.  Palm recognition is good.  The finger navigation works reliably, unlike other note apps like Quill.  All the below notwithstanding, this is the best note taking app on the market.  What I'd love to see (and pay for) in subsequent versions:  - Sync with other devices.  Not just export PDFs to dropbox, but have up-to-date editable notebooks available on both my phone and tablet (and desktop -- one day?)  - Hi-lighters  - The ability to reorganize notebook order on the home screen.  Right now they're just chronological.  - Better eraser.  Now it's a fixed number of pixels, regardless of zoom.  Would rather have it scale, to erase fine strokes more easily.  - Ability to adjust ink stroke properties (e.g. color) after it's on paper.  - "Handwriting mode" (option to get rid of pressure sensitivity.  Important for drawing, less so for writing.)  - Over-rule auto screen timeout.
Very comfortable and fast!
This is fantastic since I use custom from CM9, will continue and recommend for all Galaxy Note users even into CM10

I've tried about a dozen handwriting apps on my Xoom and Nexus 7 and this one is on top of my list. I've been using Papyrus with a passive stylus and the results are just as good as what I could get with Antipaper Notes, my 2nd favorite handwriting app. Papyrus is easy to use and all commands/options are conveniently located while you write. I particularly like the gestures that allow you to zoom in/out ad span the page while you write. I look forward to the final version!

I love papyrus, it does what S memo / note cannot: use vectors.  If you annotate a picture with S memo and then send it to somebody, they get a nasty surprise as all is pixelated. S memo / S note uses pixels and uses a pretty low resolution, nothing you can ever scale up without it looking really ugly. Papyrus on the other hand uses vectors, which are infinite scalable, you can print it out real big and it won't look ugly. You can also zoom in and out and scroll to make the note bigger in all directions. I use this on the Galaxy Note and love the precision it has with the stylus. Now just please add the annotation feature and I will be forever happy ;-) As this is a beta and it works really well and it is free, I will give this 5 stars. If the annotation feature makes it, I will even buy the app. Keep up the good work guys!
Has pressure sensitivity on cm9 with galaxy note and supports button on pen!  Please add png export

With its support of S-Pen, this is the best sketching app for Galaxy Note, for sure. only 2 requests at this moment: please add text support, and make the configurable folder for storing the working files for easy sync with clouds (or integrate the cloud upload into the app!)  Good work!

I really like the unlimited page size and the one tap erase and am hoping the next update will install the ability to delete memos and give me a few of the tools. I just won't use it, yet.

I was using this on Galaxy Note, it is hands down the best pen app in Android. I'm an extensive Onenote2010 user on a tablet PC. Why can't Samsung make something like this? Why can't Microsoft add inking in Onenote? I didn't have my hopes high, but Papyrus is really easy to use for writing notes with the pen, and quickly erasing with fingers is very easy. Can't believe this app didn't win first prize on Samsung Spen developer contest.  The only con that I see for now is that it doesn't support ICS, so I'm stuck with the sucky slow/lagging Samsung S-note app. I'm actually not writing any notes for now. ICS, there's also an option to show where the pointer dot is so it'll get even better once Papyrus supports ICS.  For the future, it would be nice if it can sync notes on Dropbox or somewhere on the cloud so that I don't lose the notes. A PC version note viewer/PDF converter would be nice too.

I have been using this App for some days and I am very well impressed. The writing with SPen is very responsive and smooth. It is far better than Skich and it provides features that overcome S Memo's limitations. However, to be a full fledged note taking App, it should also include the following features:  - detect & enhance basic shapes (oval, rectangle, triangle, etc) - import images/photos as objects - resize/rotate of objects or groups of objects - export notes/notebooks in jpg/png (its interesting for those who wish a better integration with Evernote) - export notes in standard vector graphics format (e.g., svg) - additional brush/pen types (e.g., highlight marker, pencil, paint brush, etc) - Pinch to zoom
Just what is required to make use of the pen. Brilliant.  Integration into OneNote would be the ultimate. Is this feasible? I'd pay for it if it was.

Let me be clear: this is the best implementation I've seen of the S Pen by far. It leaves Samsung's own S Memo far behind, at least until that Premium Suite drops.  Pressure sensitivity actually works and shows several levels. Notes can be expanded with two-finger scrolling both vertically and horizontally. Transition between landscape and portrait mode is seamless. I don't know how they do it, but the pen just seems to work better than on any other app. All of the other note-taking apps, especially those using the keyboard, are dead to me.  And of course then you have the beautiful, simple user interface that lets you do the things you actually want to do with one click.  It's clear that the creator wants to be make something more than "another note-taking app", so I'm sure there are a lot more features coming. Although it's not adequate for heavy drawing, but then there are other aps for that. And for now it's all free!
Very good note taking app. Erasing with the figure is very cool and being able to plant your hand on the screen without it making marks is very nice. Much better than the stock note taking app.

I've got an HTC Flyer with the active stylus and I've always wanted something that's more drawing-oriented than the base pen tools that came with device. Papyrus delivers a solid, basic drawing system with user-definable colors, pen sizes and pressure support on the stylus. It's a very, very good start to a more complete drawing/painting application.  While I would love to see some tool variety and a few extra features, I know this tool will be on my Flyer from this point on!

I wasn't sure how to delete a note, so wrote to them and within a few minutes I got back a reply - - "Yes, you can delete notes by long pressing on a note thumbnail in the "notebook view" (main page after launching Papyrus). Delete and rename options will appear in the upper right. You can also click multiple notes in that mode to delete them at the same time. You can also long press on notebooks to rename or delete them as well."  Fantastic customer support.  Highly recommend this app.  Am using it on my Transformer Prime.

Works flawlessly on my flyer, especially for a beta! The interface is very clean and intuitive. I love the feature of using your finger as a quick eraser.
